title: 109_hr5357
content: The "Research for Competitiveness Act" may be cited as the short title. It includes provisions for National Science Foundation industrially-relevant research awards. The "Research for Competitiveness Act" authorizes the National Science Foundation to award grants to early-career scientists and engineers for high-risk, high-return research relevant to industry. Recipients must be tenure-track assistant professors or equivalent, with awards lasting 5 years at $50,000 per year, with potential for additional funding from industry matches. The "Research for Competitiveness Act" authorizes the National Science Foundation to award grants to early-career scientists and engineers from institutions of higher education or nonprofit research organizations in the US. Applicants must submit a CV, research interests, letters of recommendation, and other required materials for review by the Director. The Director shall convene review panels to recommend finalists for awards based on application materials. Finalists will be interviewed by industry representatives, and awards will be given based on expert recommendations. Criteria for evaluation include leadership potential at the frontiers of knowledge. The Director will convene review panels to recommend finalists for awards based on application materials, with criteria including leadership potential at the frontiers of knowledge, innovative research, past creativity, and industry relevance. Authorization of appropriations for the National Science Foundation is set at $3,000,000 for 2007, $6,000,000 for 2008, $9,000,000 for 2009, $12,000,000 for 2010, and $15,000,000 for 2011. The Department of Energy will provide research awards for industrially-relevant projects. The Department of Energy will award competitive grants to early-career scientists and engineers for high-risk, high-return research in energy-related areas. The program allows participation from various Department of Energy organizations and offers awards up to $50,000 per year for a duration of up to 5 years. The Department of Energy offers competitive grants of up to $50,000 per year for up to 5 years to early-career scientists and engineers for high-risk, high-return research in energy-related areas. Recipients may receive an additional $50,000 annually as a match to industry funding. Eligible individuals must be in a tenure-track position at a US institution of higher education or a nonprofit research organization. Applicants must submit a curriculum vitae or resume for initial application. The Under Secretary requires a curriculum vitae, research interests, letters of recommendation, and any other materials for the application process. Review panels recommend finalists for the award, who are then interviewed by experts for final selection. The Under Secretary awards grants based on recommendations from review panels composed of industry representatives. Criteria for evaluation include leadership potential, innovative research nature, past creativity, and industry relevance. In awarding grants, the Under Secretary may prioritize applications involving collaboration with Department of Energy National Laboratories. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2007-2011 is specified. SEC. 4. DEFINITION. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in this Act as per the Higher Education Act of 1965.
